nit: A few lines in here exceed 72 char limit
Oops can't believe I missed that
nit: "with the"
Done

Directly looking at the filesystem seems problematic if PDC were to change this some day. Why not use the mapper interface to find the dumps and read their Path property?

busctl call xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper /xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper GetSubTreePaths sias "/xyz/openbmc_project/dump/bmc" 0 1 xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Entry.BMC

and then read the file path

busctl get-property xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Manager /xyz/openbmc_project/dump/bmc/entry/1 xyz.openbmc_project.Common.FilePath Path
I agree. +1

My preference would have been to do something like that. As far as I can tell PDC does not implement the Path property so I thought hardcoding was my only option.

```
busctl introspect xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Manager /xyz/openbmc_project/dump/bmc/entry/2
NAME                                    TYPE      SIGNATURE RESULT/VALUE                             FLAGS
org.freedesktop.DBus.Introspectable     interface -         -                                        -
.Introspect                             method    -         s                                        -
org.freedesktop.DBus.Peer               interface -         -                                        -
.GetMachineId                           method    -         s                                        -
.Ping                                   method    -         -                                        -
org.freedesktop.DBus.Properties         interface -         -                                        -
.Get                                    method    ss        v                                        -
.GetAll                                 method    s         a{sv}                                    -
.Set                                    method    ssv       -                                        -
.PropertiesChanged                      signal    sa{sv}as  -                                        -
xyz.openbmc_project.Common.OriginatedBy interface -         -                                        -
.OriginatorId                           property  s         ""                                       emits-change writable
.OriginatorType                         property  s         "xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Originate... emits-change writable
xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Progress     interface -         -                                        -
.CompletedTime                          property  t         1682545314000000                         emits-change writable
.StartTime                              property  t         1682545313999245                         emits-change writable
.Status                                 property  s         "xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Progress.... emits-change writable
xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Entry          interface -         -                                        -
.InitiateOffload                        method    s         -                                        -
.OffloadUri                             property  s         ""                                       emits-change writable
.Offloaded                              property  b         false                                    emits-change writable
.Size                                   property  t         356                                      emits-change writable
xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Entry.BMC      interface -         -                                        -
xyz.openbmc_project.Object.Delete       interface -         -                                        -
.Delete                                 method    -         -                                        -
xyz.openbmc_project.Time.EpochTime      interface -         -                                        -
.Elapsed                                property  t         1682545314000000                         emits-change writable
```

Ahh yep, sorry my system I was looking at had https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/49466 on it. Once that gets in we could look into making this code utilize that. For now hard coding the path is as good as we're going to get.
After dealing with a few too many weird errors, I'm always a fan of a "BMCWEB_LOG_ERROR" in these paths.
Fair point, I've added logs to the parts where we returned a 500 Internal Error from lseek() or read() fails.

Out in meta-ibm, we have a 20MB max (https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/dump/phosphor-debug-collector_%25.bbappend#L13). Could we make this configurable via a meson config option?

The size is arbitrary so I'm fine with upping it to 20MB.  

I don't know about making it a compiler option.  I'm trying to keep it in line with the existing dump flow used for /redfish/v1/Systems/<str>/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/<str>/attachment and that one is hardcoded.

Based on previous efforts like https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61131, allowing limits to be tuned via a compiler option seems like an approach that is discouraged.  If the maintainers are alright with a compiler option then I think that'd be better left to its own CL.  In that case we should add a compiler option for the existing type of dump as well.
Works for me
can we have Max size D-bus property for each Dump/DumpType, so that bmcweb can use max dump size D-bus property which can be configured runtime.

Implementing that would be a lot of extra work and involve repos outside of bmcweb.  You'd need to create a new daemon that puts the max sizes on dbus or you'd have to modify an existing daemon to add them.  If that's a direction you want to pursue then it should be a separate effort instead of part of this patch.

I think it's possible, but what is the use case for something like that?  If you need a different max size then a compiler option seems like a more reasonable direction.  You could also directly modify the value via a downstream patch if upstream doesn't approve of adding a compiler option.
yes, I agree

can we use BMCWEB_HTTP_REQ_BODY_LIMIT_MB?
which is already used in bmcweb code.
g

Does this mean there will be 'n' number of files in a dump path -- '/var/lib/phosphor-debug-collector/dumps/1' ?

I assume the dump data will be packaged into 1 single tar file.

If there are n number of files, instead of appending to dumpFiles, should we return error?

You are right and that should be an error.  In this specific case there should only be a single tar file.

I wanted getDumpFiles() to be more generic so I have that check inside of downloadDumpEntry() after getDumpFiles() returns.  I've moved it to inside of getDumpFiles().
Why is this path hardcoded?  It should be coming from dbus.

See https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61957/comment/8ba2f324_4eed3aa6/

Phosphor-debug-collector does not yet expose that path on dbus so this is the only way to know the folder location.  It can be replaced with a dbus lookup once support for that is added to phosphor-debug-collector.

> It can be replaced with a dbus lookup once support for that is added to phosphor-debug-collector.

This is going to be required before the patchset can be merged.  In parallel, there's discussions going on about moving bmcweb to non-root, for which this would immediately break.

Especially considering there's patchsets in review to do this already the expected way, I don't think it makes sense to merge this as-written.

> This is going to be required before the patchset can be merged. 

ACK

> In parallel, there's discussions going on about moving bmcweb to non-root, for which this would immediately break.

> Especially considering there's patchsets in review to do this already the expected way, ...

If you mean https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/49466 then that's planning to expose a filepath.  We'd still have to open that file so wouldn't that also get broken by moving bmcweb to non-root?

If so then is the answer to retrieve a file descriptor from dbus like we do with https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#L1960-L1982?

> > This is going to be required before the patchset can be merged. 
> 
> ACK
> 
> > In parallel, there's discussions going on about moving bmcweb to non-root, for which this would immediately break.
> 
> > Especially considering there's patchsets in review to do this already the expected way, ...
> 
> If you mean https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/49466 then that's planning to expose a filepath.  We'd still have to open that file so wouldn't that also get broken by moving bmcweb to non-root?

I thought the latest state of the art was to pass a file descriptor, although I haven't really tracked the above discussion.

> 
> If so then is the answer to retrieve a file descriptor from dbus like we do with https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#L1960-L1982?

Yeah, exactly.

So does my patch need to be compatible with the current approach of passing a filepath or does https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/49466 need to be pushed to instead expose a file descriptor before it gets merged?

I would prefer it to use the latest interface, rather than checking in code that we know needs to almost immediately change.  If that doesn't work, let me know, and we can probably work out a different staging plan.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/49466 is being change to expose the file handle instead of a filepath.  I'm going to switch this patch to WIP until it's been updated to remove the use of a hardcoded filepath
use std::ifstream ?
Doing it this way keeps it consistent with the file I/O from elsewhere in this file such as within requestRoutesDBusEventLogEntryDownload().
return?
You're right, I've added it.
In the error paths of this function, the file descriptor 'fd' is not being closed.
I've added close() to the error paths
Consider using fstat() to get the file size instead of lseek(). While other parts of this file use lseek(), it may be more robust to use fstat() instead.

My preference is to have all parts of this file use the same approach.  I don't know if one should be preferred over the other.  If fstate() is preferrable to lseek() then I'd rather have that be a separate patch that replaces all instances.
Should this be part of meson tuning?

That was discussed as part of this thread https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61957/comment/5f810c88_f508949e/

Please refer to that discussion and follow up there if you have further concerns.
Should the privilege be getLogEntryCollection?

No, getLogEntryCollection is for /redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/LogServices/Dump/Entries which is a collection of LogEntry resources.  We are retrieving the attachment for a singular LogEntry.

Note that the is the same way other privileges for other /attachments are handled in this file:

inline void requestRoutesDBusEventLogEntryDownload(App& app)
{
    BMCWEB_ROUTE(
        app,
        "/redfish/v1/Systems/<str>/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/<str>/attachment")
        .privileges(redfish::privileges::getLogEntry)
        
        
inline void requestRoutesPostCodesEntryAdditionalData(App& app)
{
    BMCWEB_ROUTE(
        app,
        "/redfish/v1/Systems/<str>/LogServices/PostCodes/Entries/<str>/attachment/")
        .privileges(redfish::privileges::getLogEntry)
Posting responses to a couple of questions.  I'll work on making the other changes
Please try to fill these out correctly.
Please use std::filesystem::path::operator\ for this so that we don't have problems in the case of unescapable paths.
Missing range check.
Technically this will never have a problem, but you're taking a reference to an rvalue, which is non-intuitive.  Please remove the &

This is fine as written, because we do this everywhere, but at some point I'd like to see this rewritten with an RAII object like:
https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/master/libs/beast/doc/html/beast/ref/boost__beast__http__file_body.html
Not sure how pedantic I want to be here, but technically this is off_t
secure coding guidelines would say this needs to be < 0 to avoid an underflow condition.
nit (change if you want).  This can be deduplicated with line 805;  Once the read is done, you can close it.
If this is the only use, why do we even have the arg?  Are we planning on reusing this method later?

In part I wanted handleLogServicesDumpEntryDownGet() to mirror the format we use for related uptree functions like handleLogServicesDumpEntryGet().

We have two existing URIs for downloading attachments:

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#L1933

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#L3993

Those handlers have long lambda functions that we'd want to get rid of anyway.  We're adding a third URI for downloading attachments.  The flows are similar enough that they should be able to reuse some of the same code.  I don't want to combine refactoring on top of adding new functionality so my thought was to lay some of the groundwork now to make future refactoring easier.  

Is that alright?  If not then I can remove this for now to streamline the patch a bit.

> In part I wanted handleLogServicesDumpEntryDownGet() to mirror the format we use for related uptree functions like handleLogServicesDumpEntryGet().

If we're duplicating code, there's no reason for it to be identical.

> 
> We have two existing URIs for downloading attachments:
> 
> https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#L1933
> 
> https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#L3993
> 
> Those handlers have long lambda functions that we'd want to get rid of anyway.  

+ 1 million to shortening our long lambda methods.

> We're adding a third URI for downloading attachments.  The flows are similar enough that they should be able to reuse some of the same code.  I don't want to combine refactoring on top of adding new functionality so my thought was to lay some of the groundwork now to make future refactoring easier.

I'm not quite following, let me make sure I understand:
1. This method is identical to the other method that does the same thing.
2. At some point in the future, you'll move over those other two lambdas to use this method, so the arg will be neccesary then.

If my understanding is correct, then yes, it's fine.  Thank you for cleaning things up.

> 
> Is that alright?  If not then I can remove this for now to streamline the patch a bit.

Nope, don't worry about it;  Now that I understand the plan, it's fine.
